raw_text:
US trade gap hits record in 2004
 
 The gap between US exports and imports hit an all-time high of $671.7bn (£484bn) in 2004, latest figures show.
 
 The Commerce Department said the trade deficit for all of last year was 24.4% above the previous record - 2003's imbalance of $496.5bn. The deficit with China, up 30.5% at $162bn, was the largest ever recorded with a single country. However, on a monthly basis the US trade gap narrowed by 4.9% in December to £56.4bn. The US consumer's appetite for all things from oil to imported cars, and even wine and cheese, reached record levels last year and the figures are likely to spark fresh criticism of President Bush's economic policies.
 
 Democrats claim the administration has not done enough to clamp down on unfair foreign trade practices. For example, they believe China's currency policy - which US manufacturers claim has undervalued the yuan by as much as 40% - has given China's rapidly expanding economy an unfair advantage against US competitors.
 
 Meanwhile, the Bush administration argues that the US deficit reflects the fact the America is growing at faster rate than the rest of the world, spurring on more demand for imported goods. Some economists say this may allow an upward revision of US economic growth in the fourth quarter. But others point out that the deficit has reached such astronomical proportions that foreigners many choose not to hold as many dollar-denominated assets, which may in turn harm growth. For all of 2004, US exports rose 12.3% to $1.15 trillion, but imports rose even faster by 16.3% to a new record of $1.76 trillion. Foreign oil exports surged by 35.7% to a record $180.7bn, reflecting the rally in global oil prices and increasing domestic demand. Imports were not affected by the dollar's weakness last year. "We expect the deficit to continue to widen in 2005 even if the dollar gets back to its downward trend," said economist Marie-Pierre Ripert at IXIS.
llama3.2:1b: US trade gap hits record $671.7bn (£484bn) in 2004, up 24.4% from 2003.
The deficit with China reached $162bn, the largest ever recorded with a single country.
US exports rose 12.3% to $1.15 trillion but imports rose 16.3% to $1.76 trillion, while foreign oil exports surged by 35.7% to $180.7bn.
llama3.2:3b: The US trade gap hit a record $671.7 billion in 2004, with imports rising 16.3% and exports increasing by 12.3%.
The deficit with China reached a new high of $162 billion, sparking criticism of President Bush's economic policies.
The administration argues that the deficit reflects the country's growing economy, while others warn it may harm growth due to foreigners' reluctance to hold dollar-denominated assets.
gemma2:2b: US trade gap reached a record $671.7 billion in 2004, surpassing 2003's record by 24.4%.
China was the largest contributor to the deficit at $162 billion.
Although monthly deficit decreased in December, critics claim that President Bush’s policies haven't addressed unfair trade practices, such as China's undervalued yuan.
The administration defends a faster US growth rate leading to increased demand for imports and argues it doesn't reflect an economic collapse.
However, some economists point out the significant deficit might lead to reduced foreign dollar holdings.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The US trade deficit reached a record high of $671.7 billion in 2004, with the largest gap being with China ($162 billion), up 30.5% from the previous year's imbalance (2003).
The trade surplus narrowed to £56.4 billion in December, down 4.9% compared to the previous month.
Democrats claim that Bush has not done enough to curb unfair foreign trade practices, while China's currency policy is seen as an advantage for US competitors.
The deficit will likely lead to more imports and increased demand for imported goods, potentially harming growth.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The US trade gap hit an all-time high of $671.7 billion (equivalent of £484 billion) in 2004, with a deficit on goods reaching $56.4 billion in December.
The deficit with China was the largest recorded at $162 billion.
Despite this, Democrats accuse the administration of not clamping down on unfair foreign trade practices, while Republicans argue that faster US economic growth is behind the growing imports.
qwen2.5:3b: The US trade gap reached a record of $671.7bn (£484bn) in 2004, up by 24.4% from 2003’s deficit and with the deficit to China at $162bn being its largest ever recorded single-country imbalance.
Despite monthly trade deficits narrowing slightly to £56.4bn in December, consumer demand for imports increased last year.

Critics argue that US economic policies have not addressed unfair foreign trade practices like China's undervalued currency, while the administration counters by attributing the deficit to America’s faster growth and growing demand for imported goods.
Economists note both potential benefits from a fourth-quarter growth revision and risks if foreigners reduce their holdings of dollar assets.
Exports increased 12.3% to $1.15 trillion, while imports rose 16.3% to a new record of $1.76 trillion.
Economists predict the trade deficit will widen further in 2005 despite potential dollar recovery.
opencoder:1.5b: The US trade gap hits record in 2004, latest figures show.
The Commerce Department reported that during last year, the trade deficit for all exports was 24.4% above the previous record of $496.5bn compared to 2003's imbalance of $496.5bn.
The largest ever recorded is with China up 30.5% at $162bn.
In December, the US trade gap narrowed by 4.9% in the month-to-month basis to about $56.4bn compared to a similar figure in the previous year.
The US consumer's appetite for all things from oil to imported cars, and even wine and cheese, reached record levels last year.

Democrats believe that China's currency policy which US manufacturers claim has undervalued the yuan by as much as 40% could give China's rapidly expanding economy an unfair advantage against US competitors.
Meanwhile, The Bush administration argues that the America is growing at faster rate than the rest of the world spurring on more demand for imported goods.
Economists say this may allow an upward revision of US economic growth in the fourth quarter.
But they point out that the deficit has reached such astronomical proportions which could harm growth.
Foreign oil exports surged by 35.7% to a record figure of $180.7bn, reflecting the global increase in global oil prices and increasing domestic demand.
Foreigners may choose not to hold as many dollar-denominated assets as they did last year, further spurring economic growth.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and preserves key ideas, but it does not include any explanations or justifications for the US trade gap with China.
The text also does not provide a clear explanation of the US trade deficit in 2004.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The U.S. trade gap reached a record high in 2004 with an import deficit of $671.7 billion.
The total trade imbalance for last year stood at $496.5 billion, the largest ever recorded by a single country.
China contributed the largest monthly imbalance of $162 billion since records were set that year.
U.S. consumers still bought numerous imported goods like oil, cars, wine, and cheese throughout 2004.
Democrats claim the U.S. administration hasn't adequately addressed unfair practices towards China's currency policies, particularly regarding the yuan being undervalued by 40%.
Meanwhile, the Bush administration argues that faster imports boost demand for US goods, possibly boosting economic growth.
However, economists note that the $671.7 billion deficit may erode foreign investment and harm growth due to a weak dollar.
tinyllama:1.1b: Following a record high in 2004, the US trade gap grew by 4.9% in December and stood at $56.4 billion.
Democrats claim that the administration's policies have not been enough to curb unfair foreign trade practices and that the US deficiit reflects the growing rate of economic growth in the USA.
While some economists suggest this may lead to a downward revision of US economic growth, foreigners are choosing not to hold as many dollar-denominated assets, potentially harming growth.
The export deficiit rose 12.3% in 2004 and imports surged by 16.3%, reflecting the rairiy in global oil prices and increased domestic demand.

Imports were not significantly affected by the weakness of the dollar last year, while exports grew despite a dip in US consumer's appetite for all things foreign, leading to an overall trade deficiit of $671.7bn in 2004, a record high for the USA.
However, Democrats claim that China's currency policy has given Chinese goods an unfair advantage against US competitors.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The US trade gap hit a record high of $671.7bn in 2004, according to the latest figures from the Commerce Department.
This represents a 24.4% increase on last year's record imbalance and is the largest trade deficit ever recorded with just one country - China.
In December, the US trade gap decreased by 4.9% to £56.4bn, although Democrats argue that this underscores how unfair China's currency policy has been for American manufacturers.
Meanwhile, the Bush administration argues that the US deficit reflects the fact that America is growing at a faster rate than the rest of the world, spurring on more demand for imported goods.

Some economists suggest that this may allow an upward revision of US economic growth in the fourth quarter, but others argue that the increase in the trade gap may also impact global growth due to reduced foreign investment and oil exports, particularly from the US.
phi:2.7b: In 2004, the US trade gap reached an all-time high of $671.7 billion with imports exceeding exports by a significant margin.

This is due to the increasing demand for imported goods, particularly from China where the deficit was 30.5% higher than in 2003 and $162 billion, making it the largest ever recorded bilateral trade gap with a single country.

Democrats argue that the administration has not done enough to address unfair foreign trade practices such as currency manipulation by China, which they believe gives China an unfair advantage over US manufacturers.
Meanwhile, the Bush administration argues that the US deficit reflects its faster economic growth.
However, the US is facing criticism for its increasing trade gap and some economists are calling for measures to reduce it, including addressing unfair foreign trade practices.
orca-mini:3b: In 2004, the US trade gap hit an all-time high of $671.7bn, while the Commerce Department reported the trade deficit for all of last year was 24.4% above the previous record - 2003's imbalance of $496.5bn.
The US deficit with China, up 30.5% at $162bn, was the largest ever recorded with a single country.
However, on a monthly basis the US trade gap narrowed by 4.9% in December to £56.4bn.
Democrats claim the administration has not done enough to clamp down on unfair foreign trade practices.
The Bush administration argues that the US deficit reflects the fact the America is growing at faster rate than the rest of the world, spurring on more demand for imported goods.
Some economists say this may allow an upward revision of US economic growth in the fourth quarter.
But others point out that the deficit has reached such astronomical proportions that foreigners may choose not to hold as many dollar-denominated assets, which may in turn harm growth.
hermes3:3b: US trade gap reaches record $671.7bn in 2004.
Deficit with China ($162bn) is highest ever with a single country, 24.4% above previous record.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: In 2004, the US trade gap reached an all-time high of $671.7 billion due to a 24.4% increase from the previous year's record deficit of $496.5 billion.
The largest deficit with a single country was recorded with China at $162 billion, up 30.5%.
Critics argue that unfair foreign trade practices have given China an unfair advantage over US competitors.
The Bush administration believes this reflects America's fast growth rate compared to the rest of the world leading to increased demand for imported goods.
Despite the criticism, economists vary in their views on whether the deficit will widen further in 2005 even if the dollar recovers.
stablelm2:1.6b: US trade deficit hits record high of $1.7bn, with China's deficit with the US being the largest ever recorded by a single country.
The deficit reflects America's growing rate relative to the rest of the world.
Exports rose 0.3% but imports surged 0.3% to a new record, contributing to the record high deficit.
Foreign oil exports also hit a record with global oil prices driving demand.
Economist Marie- Pierre Ripert predicts that even if the dollar weakens, the deficit is likely to continue widening in 2015.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In 2004, the US trade gap reached a record $671.7 billion, surpassing the previous high of $496.5 billion in 2003 by 24.4%.
China's role as the largest contributor to this deficit was significant, with imports rising 30.5% to $162 billion.
The US trade gap narrowed slightly in December but remained high at $56.4 billion.

This trend fuels criticism of President Bush's economic policies, as the growing American consumer's demand for imported goods from various sectors, including oil and luxury items, is blamed on unfair foreign trade practices, particularly China's alleged undervalued yuan.
The Bush administration attributes the deficit to the US' rapid economic growth outpacing global counterparts, fueling increased demand for imported goods.
Some economists suggest this could lead to a revision of US economic growth in the fourth quarter.
However, others caution that such an extensive trade deficit might discourage foreigners from holding dollar-denominated assets, potentially harming overall growth.
For 2004, US exports increased by 12.3% to $1.15 trillion, while imports soared 16.3% to a record $1.76 trillion.
Foreign oil exports surged 35.7% to $180.7 billion, driven by rising global oil prices and domestic demand.
Economists predict the trade deficit will widen further in 2005 despite potential dollar strength, as per Marie-Pierre Ripert of IXIS.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The US trade deficit reached a record $671.7 billion in 2004, a 24.4% increase from 2003.
The deficit with China rose 30.5% to $162 billion, the largest ever with a single country.
Despite a 4.9% narrowing in December, high consumer demand for imports, including oil and cars, fueled the overall gap.
Democrats criticized President Bush’s policies, citing unfair foreign trade practices, particularly China’s currency valuation.
The administration argued the deficit reflected strong US economic growth.
While some economists saw potential for upward growth revisions, others warned that the deficit's size could deter foreign investment in US assets.
US exports rose 12.3% to $1.15 trillion, but imports grew faster at 16.3% to $1.76 trillion, with foreign oil imports surging 35.7%.
Economists expect the deficit to widen further in 2005.
